title: Cat. 43  Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Otho, A.D. 69
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Otho  
A.D. 69 (January/April), issued by Otho  
Gold; diam. 1.9 cm; 7.25 g  
Mint: Rome  
Obverse: Head of Otho right, bare  
Inscribed: IMP.OTHO.CAESAR.AVG.TR.P  
Reverse: Securitas stands left, wreath in right hand, scepter in left  
Inscribed: SECVRITAS P R  
RIC I 9; cf. BMCRE I 19 (denarius); axis: 5:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Martin A. Ryerson, 1922.4865

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">The second of the “four emperors” of the year 69, M. Salvius Otho, an old friend of Nero, was proclaimed imperator by the Praetorian Guard, who then promptly murdered the current holder of the title, Galba. The Senate obligingly handed Otho the usual honors: they acknowledged him Augustus and Caesar, and gave him tribunician power, as the obverse inscription tells. Otho needed money fast to pay troops to fight off the next rival for the throne, Vitellius. The mint in Rome immediately got to work. The reverses of Otho’s gold and silver are desperately, almost hysterically, optimistic: they call for peace on all the lands of earth (pax orbis terrarum), victory (victoria), abundant food (Ceres), domestic bliss (Vesta), and as on this coin, Security for the Roman people (Securitas P[opuli] R[omani]). According to Tacitus, Otho committed suicide to avoid dragging out the civil war. He reigned three months.  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Tacitus, Histories 2.47–48.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 43 Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Otho, A.D. 69

</section>
